text:
Hi everyone,
How can I implement the MultiStep Form of HubSpot in the page, So that it does not add as an Iframe and as a normal form, I want to implement styling to the multi-step form but not from the in-built setup given in HubSpot rather my own via CSS or this is something not possible at the moment.
For anyone else wondering - enabling bubbles for the change event solved issue

If you're using the build-in multi-step-form functionality - it's not possible to remove the iframe for now.

My recommendations are
1. create a module that will display a form as multi-step form or let's you create your own multi-step form
2. create a multistep with a 3rd-party addon like typeform

Personally I've created several custom multi-step modules that don't rely on the multi-step functionality and also I don't like the fact that the new multi-step builder has dropped a lot of functionalities that are/were supported by the old form builder. But it's nothing anyone from outside HubSpot can change...

:wave:
I'm not sure where to ask this, so leaving my question here.

Even though I've been building themes for HubSpot CMS for a while and working with websites on HubSpot CMS, I have never used the staging feature.

Could someone explain the benefits of staging vs local development? Or describe a use case why one would need to use staging.

Thanks a lot!
<@UJAPS2K4N> maybe you can share some of your experience on the topic :relaxed:

Hey <@UMZFZHVUJ>, sure thing.

The staging is an extremly powerful tool.
One of the many usecases is to rework all existing pages without worrying about something going downhill on the live pages.

Let's put it that way:
Somebody has built a website on Growth(just to name a theme that everybody knows) and at some point this person buys a theme from you. Now - the person is in the position to rebuilt everything on your theme. There are a few options how to migrate:
• clone the pages and apply all changes to the cloned one
• simply change the template in the page-builder
Those options can lead to a lot of problems since
• cloning the page will result in a new URL. Since you can't have several pages with the same URL, you'll potentially end up in a redirect solution/rabithole. 
• your theme might be more advanced than growth and utilize custom modules. Therefore changing just the template will lead to the result that the content most likely won't be transferred automatically. 
This is where staging comes into play.
You can simply clone the existing page to staging, apply all changes, even publish it in staging and share the staging links with stakeholders. After successful approval, you can replace all published pages that were staged with a click of a button.

A few more benefits of staging:
• the URL stays the same after replacing live pages with staged pages. This means you don't have to think about redirects and such.
• Staged pages are completely seperated from live pages during the staging process. You can change content, templates, links... everything
• You can push X pages to live at once. Great for a website relaunch where you want to relaunch all pages at once
• ...
:point_up_2: Yepp. This. I use staging for literally everything, even if it's just a single new page. A lot easier than working with draft pages

Hello, I was wondering where to post this question! It's regarding Stripe's integration as a payment processor. We have a custom-built website with custom code that integrates Stripe natively through iframes. We want to activate the integration of Stripe as a payment processor in HubSpot to import data from our clients' subscriptions to HubSpot. I want to confirm if this would not affect at any time the development that we had already done and at the same time, thus continue allowing customers to continue paying in our website as they always have. We only want to use the integration to be able to bring data from our clients' subscriptions, not to charge from HubSpot. Greeting!

Wow <@UJAPS2K4N>
This is the most profound answer I could have expected!!! You should turn it into a blog post or something

Thanks so much :orange_heart:
